skills.techIntro: This section is to talk about my technical skills.
skills.hardTechnical: At École 42, I developed strong skills in C/C++ programming, efficient algorithms, operating systems like Unix/Linux, networking and protocols, and web development using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and modern frameworks. These hard skills enable me to solve complex problems and collaborate in development teams.
skills.hardExperience: In addition to my studies at École 42, I have also gained practical experience working at 42labs. This experience has allowed me to apply my technical skills in real-world projects, further enhancing my abilities in software development, debugging, and project management. Working in a collaborative environment at 42labs has also improved my communication and teamwork skills, making me a more effective and versatile developer.
skills.softText: At École 42, I've developed skills in teamwork, problem-solving, self-learning, resilience, and adaptability. These soft skills are crucial for effective collaboration, tackling challenges, and continuous learning and professional growth.

fdf.title: Fdf - Fil de Fer
fdf.description: This project consists of graphically creating a schematic representation of a terrain in relief.
fdf.description1: FdF is a project in which we convert a file with a grid of height values into a 3D wireframe using a simple graphics library called MiniLibX.
fdf.description2: The grid's rows represent the x-axis, the columns the y-axis, and the values the z-axis (altitude), creating a 3D wireframe representation.

philo.title: Philosophers
philo.description: The famous Dining Philosophers problem, all with the same basic rules.
philo.description1: This project is a training to multi-threads/multi-process programming with the use of mutex and semaphore. It contains 3 different programs simulating a twist of the famous Dining Philosophers problem, all with the same basic rules.
philo.description2: This project helps to understand the basics of functions in C. Great for improving knowledge in memory allocation and programming logic.

push-swap.title: Push Swap
push-swap.description: Is a project that involves sorting a list of integers using a limited set of operations.
push-swap.description1: The goal of the push_swap project is to sort a stack of integers using two stacks and a specific set of operations. Here's a basic overview of how the project typically works:
push-swap.description2: Stacks: The project involves two stacks, Stack A and Stack B, initially containing a random set of integers.
push-swap.description3: Operations: Students are required to implement a set of operations to manipulate the stacks.
push-swap.description4: Sorting Algorithm: The main challenge is to devise an algorithm that uses these operations to sort Stack A in ascending order while following certain constraints or optimization criteria, such as minimizing the number of operations used.
push-swap.description5: Constraints: The project typically imposes constraints on the number of operations allowed, aiming for an efficient and optimized sorting algorithm.

minishell.title: Minishell
minishell.description: This project is about creating a simple shell. Yes, a little bash.
minishell.description1: Minishell is a project focused on creating a simple, minimalistic shell interface.
minishell.description2: It demonstrates basic command-line functionalities and a lightweight environment for user commands.
